Award.AwardTitle: Between Topology and Quantum Field Theory
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides support for participation in the conference "Between Topology and Quantum Field Theory" in Austin, TX, on January 14-18, 2019. The conference is intended to be a gathering of 100-150 researchers, including graduate students, postdocs, and faculty, in mathematics and theoretical physics. It will be an opportunity for broader communities of researchers to learn about dramatic developments from the last few years as well as about the areas of the conference more broadly. To maximize its impact the conference will be broadly advertised, and funds will be provided to support travel expenses of participants who otherwise could not attend. Researchers from groups underrepresented in mathematics and theoretical physics will be prioritized in allocating these funds. To further increase the reach of the conference, audio and video from the talks will be recorded and made freely available online.

The conference will catalyze new interactions between researchers in fields bridging mathematics and physics. The specific focus will be on three overlapping areas: topological phenomena in quantum field theory, mathematical formulations of quantum field theory, and differential geometry of supersymmetry. The conference plan builds on significant recent momentum in these three areas, and includes a list of 18 confirmed speakers, including both current international leaders in these areas and up-and-coming future leaders. The conference web page is available at https://web.ma.utexas.edu/topqft/

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award provided partial support for the conference "Between Topology and Quantum Field Theory," held at the Blanton Museum of Art on the campus of UT Austin, January 14-18, 2019. The conference, with 155 participants in total, from academic institutions in eight different countries, featured talks by 21 international leaders on the connections between physics, geometry and topology. It was a broad conference, intended to survey a wide range of the latest developments, as well as to bring together a particular combination of expertise that has not appeared at other recent conferences and workshops in this area. The speakers' slides were collected and made available on the conference Web site shortly after the talks ended.

The award funds were used to provide partial support for travel and accommodation for 52 participants, mostly graduate and undergraduate students who would not have been able to attend without this support. Having the opportunity to attend these kinds of gatherings early in one's research career is an key element in the career development of a young scientist; in addition to the obvious benefit from hearing the talks up close, coming to this kind of meeting allows one to develop direct connections to a much broader intellectual community than is available at one's home institution.
